comments.commentBody: This fear, and the response of many Americans to it, has the potential of being the most powerful volley in the terrorists' salvo against any lingering international fantasy about America's human rights exceptionalism. In many parts of the world, and not just the Middle East, this fantasy has already been shot through with holes. The more holes in it Daesh can fashion with fear, the more successful they will become in their push to apocalypse. If they can make everybody fear everybody else, their goal will be met spectacularly.

1. If you were a terrorist intent on wreaking mayhem on as many innocents as possible and wanted to get into the US as soon as possible, would you a) subject yourself to two years of suspicion and scrutiny by applying for a visa or b) buy a ticket as a tourist or perhaps slip across the border at some secluded spot and get lost in a crowded city?

2. If you had to gather your family and flee your home with nothing but what you could carry, and then were taken in by another nation and given the opportunity to keep your loved ones alive, what sort of citizen do you think you would be?

NYT, please do not confuse caution with cowardice. Other wise a spot on editorial.
If we had a comprehensive immigration policy, perhaps the urge to patch up the current laws with every incident would not occur. That would require Democrats and Republicans to work together. Both sides have their sensible and their unachieveable approaches. There must be a middle ground for legislators to seek -- legislators of good will. It is time to do this!

It is precisely the REACTION to their acts their terroriss count on to accomplish their ends. The psychology of terrorism [fear --> excess govsernment reaction --> deprivation of rights --> widespread alienation from government] has been used far longer, and in a much larger conexts, than just the contemporary rise of Islamist fundamentalism. From at least the mid-19th century, the aim of terrorist tactics have been to inspire crackdowns and loss of rights that eventually turn citizens against their governments. While hardly new, this principle evidently remains lost on some would-be political leaders, notably Republican candidates for president.

It's precisely the irrational character of such reactions that make them difficult to counter. Governments can't be seen simply to ignore such attacks, but governments have limited means of finding & restraining terrorists who don't wear uniforms and therefore, seemingly could be anyone, anywhere. Cracking down on everyone, or a broad class of people (all Muslims, or all Syrians to name two) alienates whole classes of people and inadvertently proves the terrorists' point.

Citizens have a duty exercise patience & fortitude. Ghastly as the Paris attacks were, chances are greater that simply driving in a car will be fatal (~117 deaths/day, or 4k pa, in the US in 2004 [http://www.nytimes.com/2004/03/13/opinion/117-deaths-each-day.html].

Difficult, but absolutely essential: Stay Calm & Carry On.

"willing to see and say what the mob does not." This virulence on the Right is nothing less than a lynch mob.
What Paul Ryan and his confederates in the governors' mansions in the several states, and Donald Trump and Ben Carson and Ted Cruz and Marco Rubio and Jeb Bush and Chris Christie and all the other vigilantes are doing is throwing a rope around America's neck and hanging it from a tree. From Manila, President Obama has mocked the GOP/TP's fear of "widows and orphans." But great danger looms for all of us. The president's measured response to the Paris outrage is turned on its ear by the forces of fear who promise violence and ruin should one of their own replace this good and decent man in 2017. In 1941, FDR did not run from the Pearl Harbor attack; he manfully answered the challenge and won the long fight. America wins this fight with ISIS with its goodness and strength, with defiantly open borders maintained with wisdom and vigilance, a tremendous display of resolve and a willingness to shield a woman or a child from harm regardless of who they are. ISIS wins if we fit the noose of fear around our necks. The party of Lincoln counsels defeat through fear. They've arrived at the sad place of "no other way," which is not how we became the great beacon. The roster mentioned above would dim the light and seek the scared dark. America, do they speak for you?

So it's really great to be reminded that our actions need to be guided by values.  But how much do you think you really KNOW about the situation. How much real intell do you have?  "be nice", " be courageous",  " be American" , " be open and accepting" is an easy thing for a person to say if they have never experienced the horror of invasion  and let's admit it, most Americans haven't.  Personally I would like to avoid another experience like 911 as I was there. Don't you think this Immigration issue deserves more contemplation than your proposition to be  nice not afraid? Consider whether you this is an idea based on liberal reflex or actual  experience and information before you issue  the platitudes  you put forth.

The world is slow to acknowledge the religious war being perpetrated by radical Islam. Paris is not a "wake-up" call, as it is no different than Madrid, 9-11, and the scores of other mass murders that have been and are being carried out in the name of Islam. It is a continuation.
.
It's time to respond as if we are at war. Countries facing a 5th column (people fighting from within against their own country) of Muslims have every right and responsibility to infiltrate their neighborhoods, monitor their activities, close their mosques when they are used for inciting, arrest their instigators, etc.

America has a long history of hypocrisy when it comes to the disconnect between our stated ideals and the reality of our behavior. The test of a nation is not what it says or does when the choices are easy but what they say and do when it is hard.  By that standard we seem to almost always fail and those that shout the loudest about our principles when it comes to them are typically the ones who are the first to ignore them when it comes to others.

Turtle democracy.  When danger approaches we we draw into ourselves and huddle behind our thick shell.  We eschew world leadership and when we engage it is a clumsy lumbering engagement.   We retreat to our thick shell when offered the opportunity of moral leadership.  We seek the comfort of our carapace when the world looks to us for Christianity's and America's promise to help the downtrodden, to be my brother's keeper, to struggle for justice and human dignity.   We should not be surprised that the turtle is considered unsuited for the mantle of global leadership.  We should not be surprised that  peace and justice in the world advance at a turtle's pace.   And we should remember that the turtle, left to itself, also falls victim to loss of habitat, fierce predators and disease.   Turtle democracy?

The price of fear directly correlates to the reaction to fear.

Unfortunately, in the Land of the Fearful and the Home of the Knaves, Grand Old Phear holds a strategic edge at using fear to drive public policy into the gutter of humanity's worst instincts.

But this is one area where Republicans understand science very, very well.

In the American Journal of Political Science, researchers studied the relationship between our deep-seated tendencies to experience fear and found that people who have a more fearful disposition also tend to be more politically conservative, and less tolerant of immigrants and people of races different from their own.

Rose McDermott of Brown University said that does not mean that every conservative has a high fear disposition:

"It's not that conservative people are more fearful, it's that fearful people are more conservative."

http://goo.gl/PDPaGK

Psychologists also found that conservatives are fundamentally more anxious than liberals, which may be why they typically desire stability, structure and simple, clear answers even to complicated questions.

“Conservatism, apparently, helps to protect people against some of the natural difficulties of living,” says social psychologist Paul Nail of the University of Central Arkansas.

http://goo.gl/kpLcZm

It's fine to be frightened by reality, but it's immoral to harvest fear purely for political gain, which unfortunately is the entire Republican marketing strategy.

Fear has a conservative bias.
Here in Paris things are sort of returning to normal, and then we read about Trump and his registry.  That's scarier than anything I've seen in Paris. What's going on over there?

I live in Alaska. You can be sure the one or two bear attacks a year will get front page headlines. Next follows a run on Smith and Wessons. Meanwhile the many people dying every day by not buckling their seat belts, smoking etc will go barely noticed. It's the same with terrorism. The only way terrorists have power is if we relinquish it to them. Take a few common sense precautions, otherwise ignore them.

A government has a responsibility to protect both its people and its ideals.

But what happens when these goals come into conflict? The editorial board has been writing daily that our ideals trump everything. But practical realities require a more measured approach, as every president, including FDR and Obama, have done.

No, we don't have to imprison or even register every Muslim American. But perhaps we should scrutinize suspect groups more carefully before we let them into this country, before we let them buy guns and and before we let them board airplanes.

Open societies are vulnerable to the unprincipled, whether they be terrorists or hyper-partisan media people. My principles won't stop shrapnel, and while I may be willing to balance my freedom and my risk, my neighbor may not. Actually, it's clear that many of our neighbors have quickly succumbed to the negative message of the GOP, which has become a collection of doom-sayers.

What actually is happening in Western societies? Is it simply down to the economy that has changed over the past decades? Has this stirred anger and fear on levels not well enough understood to be articulated. but real enough to be manipulated? Looking for answers only in America may blind us to a more widespread change in the West.

When the drafters wrote the Constitution, they spent over four months on the task, with much debate and supportive writing. The Bill of Rights took another four years. Now, however, the House of Representatives can whip up an anti-Obama bill in hours, and can change the spirit of the Republic with little beyond fear and Twitter.

It is one thing to talk about fearful ignorance on the part of Americans looking for safety in a world that suddenly seems more dangerous. It is quite another thing to look at the politicians who would deliberately cultivate that fear - and ignorance - for political power.

Scare people enough, feed them a steady diet of misinformation and outright lies, and they'll give you anything for the illusion of safety. Fear (and anger) are being used to make people stop thinking and react blindly - and turn to people who do not have their best interests at heart. This is an old, bloody tale seen time and time again in history, when people go running to 'Strong' leaders, and terrible crimes are committed by those who rule on the basis of fear.

Daesh is trying to terrify us - that's what terrorism is after all - because giving in to fear gives them power over us. That is the same goal of those in this country amplifying the terror - they too want power over us. They are not acting out of fearful ignorance. They know exactly what they are doing.

Here's a simple test of their motives. The Republican House passed a measure (with the help of some cowardly Democrats) calling for stricter screening of Syrian and Iraqi refugees, and personal guarantees from the top 3 officials who would have to sign off on each individual case. Was there anything in that bill that would have increased funding for this? Hiring more people to carry it out? Nothing?

Don't let our political terrorists win.

The Constitution does not oblige us to suicide in the name of civil liberties.  Neither does it oblige us to a fortress in the name of national security.  Those of us who are neither Left or Right continue to wait for a balanced discussion between the issues of protecting us from mass murder by terrorists while simultaneously protecting our civil liberties.  Jefferson was not casual about the order in which he declared the self-evident truths, nor the necessity of their connection:  Life, liberty, and the pursuit of happiness.

Fear is best responded to as an informative response to a threat.   It should be informative not decisive.   Decisions made based on fear are most often poorly constructed and clumsily executed, it is panic.  Using fear as an informative reference in decision making better provides appropriate safety precautions.  Fear of fire results in fire prevention regulations and behaviors.  It does not ban fire or result in the refusal to use it appropriately and with caution.   The same with water and drowning  or strangers and social behavior.  I fear terrorism and terrorists.  I do not fear Syrians or Muslims.  I fear refugees left with no home and no assistance, desperate people are in survival mode. I do not fear reugees who are treated with dignity and provided both refuge and hope.  Fear is informative when it is not allowed to be decisive.

It is okay to be afraid. It is impossible for most people living in or near Paris right now not to be at least a little afraid, I think. Probably true for any major European city. And yet that doesn't mean that we should let our fear cloud our judgment any more than it probably naturally does. That does not mean that we should use fear to justify discrimination, or let fear dictate how we view entire groups of people. We should remember that people fleeing their countries have also been living in fear. It is our responsibility to create a culture of life, and that involves inviting life into it.

I am much more cynical than the NYTimes about recent calls from political leadership to bar Syrian refugees.  The men and women who make these statements don't necessarily believe in the rationale behind them.  Instead, they seek only to curry favor and support from their constituencies.  Faithful leadership involves calling your constituents to live up to their better angels.  What we see here is the opposite of that, a devolution to the basest instincts of hatred and fear.
